title: Loved it
comment: Great app. I have it on my HTC phone and I able to snap great pictures like a standard camera.

Open Camera is the best free camera app. I have never spent money on a camera app, though, so Open Camera could very well be the best camera app ever. It's robust, stable, and under GPL.  The interface is clunky. For example, as soon as you select an option such as ISO or focus in the "dot" menu, the menu closes. To set ISO, focus and stabilization at once, for instance, requires three trips to the menu. This renders the app effectively useless for still photography outside of landscapes and portraits of very patient people.  Where Open Camera shines is motion. Resolution, bitrate and approx. frame rate can all be adjusted. You can set one of numerous crop guides, from native to beyond Cinemascope. Compass and horizon can be displayed in the UI, and focus and exposure can be locked. If you're looking to get the highest quality video out of your Android under controlled or rehearsed conditions, Open Camera is well worth trying.   I can't give Open Camera above three stars, because in addition to the frustrating menu operation, it doesn't support saving to external SD, -- crippling its strengths as a video recorder, especially since the app supports 4K capture.

I tried to like it. Liked the idea of the Open Camera, the results could be good quality pictures. It's obviously not as smooth looking as the offerings from the main players but all of the options and functionality is there - just packaged more plainly.  My main gripe, and the reason I no loinger use this as my default camera app is stablility. It would crash the camera frequently, (~40% of times the app was opened the use would end because it had crashed, not because I had closed the app). I was then unable to use ANY camera application without doing a reboot. If attempting to use the camera shortcut from the lockscreen (go to camera without unlocking) the crash rate was close to 100%  Really, you want your phone camera to hand to catch 'snaps' that appear quickly. This app is too slow and clunky for that. It does take superior pictuires to the offering from Google and Cyanogenmod (to my untrained eye) but neither of them crash a tenth as often.  There may be some scope for this as a 'museum tour' camera app, where the superior quality pictures could be a plus if they ironed out some of the stability issues, but it's got a LONG way to go before it's your default camera app.

title: Lots of potential.
comment: I love that this is open source and actively maintained. If I chose to spend more time with it, I could possibly contribute to improving the app. However, as with most open source apps, there are downsides: user interface, odd behavior with some phones. In my case, it's a great photo app that I cannot use in certain situations. Those being: taking photos for other apps (for some reason the image rotates), taking photos without shutter lag. These issues are likely fixable, but it's difficult to tell if multiple users experience the same issues. I would love to see a discussion forum develop for this app so the community can sort out issues across multiple devices for the developer.

comment: I have Galaxy S4+ (I9506) and my first test video with 720p/120fps/10Mbs was simply amazing, something that blowed away other apps with smooth, quality video, the camera is one of the best too. title: Love this
comment: With every iteration of Android version, there seems to be ever more restrictions. After the new Google Camera fail for me personally (just hated the function follows form approach), I tried several other cameras. Many somehow wasn't completely compatible with the LG F6 that I'm trying out with, and not to mention ad banners galore among other things. I'm a little skeptical about this camera software at first, but it gave better results than the OEM LG software, has the ability to store to SD card (which the new Google Camera doesn't. it's impossible with small internal storage phones). It has all the controls in one place, which is unconventional, but something I love. There are odd but useful features like level, orientation, etc. The AF is pretty accurate if not fast (unlike Google Camera), and you can adjust quite a few things DURING video taping, such as turning on the light, refocusing and zooming, etc. You can do AE Lock, something that's tremedously useful that few others seems to offer (if any). It's a truly functional camera, with solid features. Wishing for HDR and Panorama. Hope it grows to be the swiss army knife of android cameras.

comment: Trusted this when taking the video of my daughter's very first stage performance in school. Resulting video was very poor. Movement was very robotic. There was a green line at the top of the frame. I should have known better than to trust this app to preserve a very special memory for my family. Uninstalling.

I'd recommend testing a new camera app first before using it on your special one-time memory... With 1000s of Android devices, it's impossible to test on everything. Video recording is something that may work on many devices but not all, and it may depend on what parameters have been set (so one camera app may work on a device while others don't).

I tried to adjust it when it auto, macro, and manual and it kept auto focusing. The continuous focus works excellent though. Android doesn't support manual focus (the "manual mode" means it only autofocuses when you touch to focus). HDR is supported but only on some devices (that have support for it in hardware). Doing HDR for all devices ("in software") is a possibility, though more complex to do, and not as good as hardware support.

title: A few Bugs to Fix and some Features not as usable as they could be.
comment: On HTC One (M7):  The "Save Location" requires you to enter a Directory by typing it in, are we supposed to know these, would be easier to type it in by Keyboard.  For Video Resolution it says 2 choices for 1920x1088 Video (both same File size) and also 1440x1088 and 1088x1088, how about 1920x1080 ...  Uses very high numbered Resolution Ratios, example 1920x1088 is 30:17 and 2688x1520 is 168:95 (4MP Photo)., usually 1920x1080 (which is NOT a choice) would be 16:9 Ratio.  --- Auto-Stabilize would be better if it worked for Video.  Giving 2 Stars (for "new and unfinished"), will give more after some Updates.  It is at least "OK" and not "very bad", just needs more time to develop (and some Volunteers to help with the Open Source).  A good to great effort, please continue. -*-*- Part 2: After Git'ing the Source and Loading it into Android Studio I found there seems a few warnings and the Logcat Messages say the Hardware is not being set up into the correct Modes. -- Video is < 15 FPS and thus useless !  -*-*- Part 3: Other Cameras here at GP nor HTC's have these problems, it is the Software not the Hardware where the fault lies. Thanks for reading. I'll try something else.

If other camera apps don't have the problem, it's because they don't offer all video resolutions, but pls send me Settings/About info and I can take a look. The resolutions are those returned by camera API not Open Camera. Which other camera apps offer auto-stabilise feature for video? For the logcat warnings feel free to send me and I can look.
